unnormalised: ## Lost in the Labyrinth of Legitimacy: A Hilarious Hunt for Indian IDs
normalised: ## Lost in the Labyrinth of Legitimacy: A Hilarious Hunt for Indian I-D's

unnormalised: Alright folks, buckle up, because we're diving headfirst into the wonderfully weird world of Indian government IDs. It’s a jungle out there, a bureaucratic safari if you will, and navigating it can feel like trying to find a decent signal in a basement… in Manali. Let’s be honest, who hasn’t felt the mild panic when asked for their PAN card during a seemingly innocent transaction? Or the sheer dread of remembering which document you used as proof of address *last* time?
normalised: Alright folks, buckle up, because we're diving headfirst into the wonderfully weird world of Indian government I-D's. It's a jungle out there, a bureaucratic safari if you will, and navigating it can feel like trying to find a decent signal in a basement… in Manali. Let's be honest, who hasn't felt the mild panic when asked for their P-A-N card during a seemingly innocent transaction? Or the sheer dread of remembering which document you used as proof of address last time?

unnormalised: First, there's the granddaddy of them all, the Aadhaar. That 12-digit number, seemingly insignificant, holds the key to… well, pretty much everything. Need a SIM card? Aadhaar. Opening a bank account? Aadhaar. Trying to convince your landlord you’re a responsible human being? You guessed it, Aadhaar. And don't even get me started on the biometrics. My fingerprints have been rejected so many times, I'm convinced the machines think I'm a highly sophisticated robot trying to infiltrate the system. My Aadhaar No. is 9876 5432 1012, by the way. Just kidding! (Or am I?).

My Aadhaar Number is nine eight seven six five four three two one zero one two, by the way. Just kidding! (Or am I?).

unnormalised: Then we have the PAN card. That little laminated rectangle of doom and taxes. It’s essential for anything involving money and even for some things that don't involve money. It feels like it should grant me superpowers but alas all it grants are opportunities to pay taxes. And then there's the constant fear of losing it because replacing it is more painful than a root canal performed by a chimpanzee. Mine's something like ABCDE1234F, I think.

unnormalised: Next up, the Voter ID. Proof that you’re a responsible citizen who exercises their right to choose… or just wants to avoid getting yelled at by their family during election season. Getting that photo taken felt like entering a Bollywood audition and failing miserably. The ID number will probably start with EPIC and then a string of numbers, such as EPIC12345678. Mine has seen better days, sporting coffee stains and a generally crumpled look from being shoved into wallets and bags.

unnormalised: And who can forget the driving license? Proof that you're capable of handling a vehicle without causing complete chaos on the roads of India. The test alone is an adventure. Driving through narrow gullies only to be greeted by a cow in the road, testing your patience and ability to react accordingly. DL number usually starts with some letters followed by numbers, for example, DL-TN0720240000756

unnormalised: But wait, there's more! We also have passports, birth certificates, and a whole host of other official documents that reside in dusty folders and forgotten corners of our homes, only to be unearthed during moments of desperate need. Remember that birth certificate from 16-08-1988 you need for that job application? Good luck finding it amidst the mountain of old school notebooks and wedding invitations.
